He occupies the middle ground, with his face and upper torso clearly visible. As the camera gradually pulls back, the shot transitions to a wider angle, revealing two additional figures in the foreground. These two individuals are positioned on the left and right sides of the frame, framing the elderly man in the gap between them. Their upper bodies and partial heads are visible, indicating they are in the foreground, while the elderly man remains in the middle ground. The camera maintains a level height relative to the subjects throughout the sequence, keeping all figures at eye level. The background consists of dimly lit wooden elements and traditional decor, which remain static and out of focus, emphasizing the central positioning of the elderly man and the framing effect created by the two foreground figures. The transition from the initial close-up to the wider shot smoothly incorporates the new elements into the frame without altering the central focus on the elderly man.
